item.title: Asking 60 LLMs a set of 20 questions (benchmarks.llmonitor.com)
item.description: 'Script Tests Reasoning and Creativity of 60+ Models Using Prompts'
item.content:encoded:
A script was created to ask prompts testing reasoning, instruction following, and creativity to around 60 models. The answers were stored in a SQLite database. The prompts covered various topics such as arguing for and against the use of Kubernetes, explaining quantum field theory to a high-school student, and finding the next 20 leap years. The script used a mix of APIs from different platforms. The creator plans to improve the script by using better stop sequences and prompt formatting tailored to each model.

277 Points | 154 comments

item.title: The End of the Subscription Era Is Coming (nickfthilton.medium.com)
item.description: The Impact of Subscription Models on Media and Creators
item.content:encoded:
The rise of subscription models in various industries, including media, has had a significant impact on the way businesses operate and how creators earn income. While platforms like Substack and OnlyFans offer potential for lucrative earnings, the average writer or creator may earn very little. Additionally, the increasing reliance on subscriptions for various products and services raises questions about the sustainability and affordability of this model for consumers. The cost of living crisis and the need for supplemental income in a challenging job market contribute to the appeal of these platforms for creators.

50 Points | 25 comments

item.title: Intel Announces Arm Investment, Talks Up RISC-V (www.tomshardware.com)
item.description: Intel Invests in Arm Holdings, Recognizing the Importance of Arm's Technology
item.content:encoded:
Intel has announced that it has made an investment in Arm Holdings, joining the list of Arm's anchor investors. The head of Intel's foundry business unit confirmed that the investment was made because Arm's technology is strategically important for both Intel Foundry Services and Altera FPGA unit. Intel recognizes the importance of Arm's instruction set architecture (ISA) in a wide range of applications and aims to collaborate further with Arm in the future.

70 Points | 25 comments

item.title: Zinc batteries that offer an alternative to lithium just got a big boost (www.technologyreview.com)
item.description: 'Eos Energy Receives $400 Million Loan from US Department of Energy for Zinc Batteries'
item.content:encoded:
The US Department of Energy has provided a $400 million loan to battery maker Eos Energy, which offers zinc-halide batteries as an alternative to lithium-ion batteries. Eos hopes that its zinc-based technology can store renewable energy at a lower cost than lithium-ion batteries. The loan is the first of its kind from the DOE's Loan Program Office to a battery maker focused on alternatives to lithium-ion cells. The funding will support the expansion of Eos's manufacturing capacity.

6 Points | 0 comments

item.title: Lab-grown Meat is not a Climate Change Solution (www.climatedrift.com)
item.description: 'Lab-grown Meat Unlikely to Mitigate Greenhouse Gas Emissions from Livestock Farming', Says Expert
item.content:encoded:
Lab-grown meat is unlikely to be a viable solution for mitigating greenhouse gas emissions from livestock farming. While it offers the allure of reducing emissions while still enjoying meat, the technology faces significant challenges in scaling up production and may not even work at the proposed scale. Additionally, there are already existing alternatives, such as policy measures and market-driven changes, that have a better chance of achieving emission reductions. Lab-grown meat should not be considered a climate solution.

12 Points | 10 comments

item.title: Every type of plastic used by Lego (2022) (bricknerd.com)
item.description: The Many Types of Plastic Used By LEGO
item.content:encoded:
LEGO uses a variety of plastics for their bricks, including CA, HIPS, Bakelite, ABS, SAN, PP, PC, MABS, PA, POM, TP, PE, MTPO, TPU, SEBS, and PET. Each plastic has its own properties and uses, with ABS being the most commonly used since 1963. LEGO is also investing in developing sustainable materials and has already started using plant-sourced polyethylene and phasing out plastic shopping bags.

item.title: PAROL6 Desktop Robot Arm (github.com)
item.description: 'PAROL6: A High-Performance 3D-Printed Desktop Robotic Arm with Open-Source Design'
item.content:encoded:
PAROL6 is a high-performance 3D-printed desktop robotic arm that aims to mimic industrial robots in terms of design and usability. The control software, GUI, and STL files are open-source, allowing users to build their own PAROL6 robot by following the provided instructions. The project welcomes donations, advice, and contributions to support its open-source nature. The code and STL files are under the GPLv3 License.

item.title: Birth of the Gentoo Linux Distribution (www.funtoo.org)
item.description: 'The Potential of Linux and Dealing with Difficult Developers: Daniel Robbins' Linux Journey'
item.content:encoded:
Daniel Robbins shares his Linux journey, from becoming a Stampede Linux developer to starting his own distribution called Enoch. He emphasizes the potential of Linux to change, improve, and break things, as well as the importance of the Linux community. Robbins also discusses his experience dealing with difficult developers and offers advice on managing them.

It also has a privacy policy and terms of service that have been updated. The purpose of the Chrome Web Store is to provide users with a curated collection of apps and extensions for their Chrome browser.

item.title: A History of Carrying Capacity (www.wsj.com)
item.description: 'Equality in Pockets': The Fight for Gender Equality in Clothing
item.content:encoded:
In the late 19th century, women demanded 'equality in pockets' as they noticed a divergence in the development and availability of pockets in men's and women's clothing. This article highlights the historical context of pockets and how they became a symbol of gender inequality. The demand for equal pockets was seen as a part of the broader fight for women's rights, including the right to vote.

6 Points | 0 comments

item.title: The U.S. housing market vs. the Canadian housing market (awealthofcommonsense.com)
item.description: Canadian Housing Prices Continue to Soar, Outpacing U.S. Market
item.content:encoded:
Canadian housing prices have continued to rise at an alarming rate, with a 142% increase since 2005 on a real basis. This is in stark contrast to the U.S. housing market, which has seen a more modest 26% increase over the same period. The differences between the two markets become even more pronounced when comparing housing price gains to disposable income gains. While U.S. incomes have kept pace with housing prices, Canadian incomes have not, leading to a significant affordability issue in Canada.

96 Points | 232 comments

item.title: The Development of the M1 Garand and Its Implications (acoup.blog)
item.description: 'The M1 Garand: A Missed Opportunity for US Rifle Development'
item.content:encoded:
The M1 Garand, considered the best battle rifle of World War II, had a significant impact on subsequent US rifle development. While it provided advantages such as increased rate of fire and improved accuracy, it missed the opportunity to become a modern assault rifle. The US did not field its first true assault rifle until two decades after the concept was invented by the Germans. The article explores the development of the M1 Garand and the factors that influenced its design.

item.title: The Development of the C Language (2003) (cm.bell-labs.co)
item.description: 'The Development and Evolution of the C Programming Language'
item.content:encoded:
This paper discusses the development of the C programming language, its influences, and the conditions under which it was created. It highlights the evolution of C from its parent language BCPL and its grandparent language BCPL. The paper also mentions the significant periods of changes in the language and its association with the Unix operating system. It concludes by noting that C has become one of the dominant languages in the computer industry today.

item.title: Skio (YC S20) – Subscriptions for Shopify, ReCharge Migrations Is Hiring (skio.com)
item.description: 'Skio: A Startup Helping Brands Sell Subscriptions on Shopify with a Unique Business Model'
item.content:encoded:
Skio is a startup that helps brands on Shopify sell subscriptions and stands out with its transaction fee business model. The company has a flat organizational structure, minimal meeting culture, and a big long-term vision for building network effects. The founder, Kennan, has a track record of success and an EV-based decision-making approach. Skio is currently hiring for various positions in engineering, product, sales, customer experience, growth, and more.

item.title: Existing in an Un-Simulated Reality (iahwrites.substack.com)
item.description: 'Existence in an Un-Simulated Reality: A Theory on the Feeling of Consciousness'
item.content:encoded:
The author proposes a theory that even if a simulation of reality is never run, it would still feel real to the actors inside it. This theory is based on the idea that all possible states of a complex system already exist, and calculating them is not necessary for them to feel conscious. The author acknowledges that this theory does not negate the existence of choice and plans to explore community in NYC in future posts.

item.title: Public restrooms are hard to find in America (www.washingtonpost.com)
item.description: 'The Problem of Inaccessible Public Restrooms in America'
item.content:encoded:
Public restrooms are hard to find in America, with only eight public toilets for every 100,000 people. This poses a problem for millions of Americans suffering from medical conditions, as well as unhoused individuals, older adults, and pregnant individuals. The lack of accessible public restrooms can lead to anxiety and avoidance of going out. This article highlights the importance of addressing this issue for the well-being of various populations.

item.title: Dennis Austin, developer of PowerPoint, has died (www.washingtonpost.com)
item.description: 'Dennis Austin, Principal Software Developer of PowerPoint, Dies at 76'
item.content:encoded:
Dennis Austin, the principal software developer of PowerPoint, has passed away at the age of 76. Austin played a significant role in shaping how information is communicated in modern society through the development of PowerPoint. The software, which was released in 1987, revolutionized the creation of slides and became a ubiquitous tool in offices, classrooms, and government agencies. Despite its widespread use, PowerPoint has also faced criticism for its potential to create mind-numbing presentations filled with bullet points. Austin's contributions to the software were instrumental in its success.

140 Points | 85 comments

item.title: The Telescript Programming Language (en.wikipedia.org)
item.description: 'Telescript: An Agent-Oriented Programming Language for Uploading Programs to Servers'
item.content:encoded:
Telescript is an agent-oriented programming language developed by General Magic as part of the Magic Cap system. It allowed end-user devices to upload programs to servers and take advantage of their capabilities. However, General Magic failed to find a niche in the market and Telescript services were eventually deprecated. The language was object-oriented and used a modified C-like syntax. It introduced the concepts of agents and places, which interacted with each other to perform tasks.

11 Points | 1 comments

item.title: Morocco earthquake kills more than 1,000 (www.nbcnews.com)
item.description: 'Morocco Earthquake Claims Over 1,000 Lives and Devastates Historic Sites: Live Updates'
item.content:encoded:
At least 1,037 people have been killed and over 1,200 injured in a 6.8-magnitude earthquake that struck Morocco. The epicenter was in the Moroccan High Atlas mountain range, southeast of Marrakech. Rescue efforts are underway, with the Moroccan army mobilizing search and rescue teams using helicopters and drones. The U.S. Embassy in Rabat has extended condolences and is not aware of any U.S. nationals affected.

136 Points | 86 comments

item.title: Eio 1.0 – Effects-based IO for OCaml 5 (icfp23.sigplan.org)
item.description: 'Eio 1.0 - Effects-based IO for OCaml 5' to be Presented at ICFP 2023
item.content:encoded:
This session at ICFP 2023 will discuss Eio 1.0, an effects-based IO stack for OCaml 5. The talk will cover its main features, including multi-core support, lock-free data structures, modular programming, interoperability with other concurrency libraries, and interactive monitoring support. The speakers will also share their experiences in porting existing applications to Eio.

item.title: Advanced NLP with SpaCy (course.spacy.io)
item.description: Mastering Natural Language Processing with spaCy
item.content:encoded:
This course on spaCy, a Python library for Natural Language Processing, covers the basics of text processing, large-scale data analysis, processing pipelines, and training neural network models. It teaches you how to extract specific information from text, combine statistical and rule-based approaches, customize spaCy's models, and build advanced natural language understanding systems. The course is free and interactive, and is taught by Ines, one of the core developers of spaCy. She specializes in modern developer tools for AI, Machine Learning, and NLP.

item.title: What happens when you shift a register by more than the register size? (devblogs.microsoft.com)
item.description: Different Processor Architectures Behave Differently When Shifting Registers
item.content:encoded:
When shifting a register by more than its size, different processor architectures exhibit different behaviors. The table provided in the article shows the behavior of various processors, including the 8086, Alpha AXP, x86-64, MIPS, PowerPC, and more. The article also mentions that the C and C++ languages leave the behavior undefined when shifting by more than the bit width of the shifted type.
